title: Corrie legend Julie Hesmondhalgh moved in with husband week after first date

We meet actress Julie Hesmondhalgh, aka Coronation Street’s Hayley Cropper, at a restaurant in Manchester just off Jack Rosenthal Way.

Appropriate, as he was one of Corrie’s first writers in the 1960s and his wife Maureen Lipman is currently in the show.

Julie bounces in, oozing warmth, all smiles and hugs.

Her almost-white blonde spiky hair is set off by a big pair of black-rimmed glasses, and she’s dressed comfortably in a black denim big-buttoned top and trousers.

She immediately orders a pot of tea and when we mention the pizza looks good she says, ‘Oh, I was going to have a salad, but stuff it, I’ll have a pizza as well.’

Her accent is pure Lancashire, ‘I’m Accrington bred through and through,’ she explains.

Julie was famous for 16 years as soap’s first transgender character in Corrie.

(Image: CAMERA PRESS/CAMERA PRESS/Chris Floyd)

Hayley was much-loved and people still do a double-take when they see Julie – even our waiter was a bit giddy.

‘I totally get it,’ she says. ‘There were moments when I was working there that the other actors and I would suddenly go, “OMG, we’re on Coronation Street !” It’s iconic.’

When Hayley succumbed to pancreatic cancer in 2014, there wasn’t a dry eye in the house as her final episode aired.

‘I was in bits myself,’ she says.

‘On my last day over 100 cast and crew came round to cheer me off, I was on the floor in a foetal position!’

Since then Julie has starred in hit series like Happy Valley and Broadchurch as well as a host of theatre productions.

Her home life is as down-to-earth as she is – Julie and hubby, screenwriter Ian Kershaw (who she calls ‘Kersh’) met on her first week of Corrie.

They have two teenage daughters, Martha and Lyss, and an 11-year-old rescue dog, a lurcher called Bridie.

(Image: Eamonn and James Clarke/EMPICS Entertainment)

They have lived in the same terraced house just outside Manchester since they got together.

‘We want that continuity for the girls, so they’ve always got the same bedroom to come back to,’ she says.

As we chat and eat and drink more tea, Julie tells us about her life in Corrie, being a mum, romance and her latest role in a brand new play…

How exactly did you and your husband meet?

It was on my first week of Corrie, he was an actor then but now is a writer – in fact, he writes for Corrie.

We became really good pals, then we went out one night for a mate’s birthday and we had been full-on flirting all night.

At the end of it I said, ‘I’m going to marry you.’

(Image: PA Wire/PA Images)

He laughed, and we kissed.

He was going for an audition the next day and I texted him saying,

‘I hope you get this job today, because I will expect to be kept in the manner I’ve become accustomed to when we get married and have our two kids.’

He texted back saying, ‘What do you want from me!?’

I said, ‘Not much, just a top wedding and kid by next Christmas!’ He answered saying, ‘Martha or Arthur?’

Our Martha was born by the next Christmas.

(Image: PA)

Wow, that was quick!

We went out on the Thursday night, I moved in with him on the following Wednesday and I was pregnant within six weeks.

We went on a road trip across America and I did a pregnancy test on Santa Barbara pier, and there is a picture of us – we got a stranger

to take it – pointing at the test saying, ‘We’ve just found out about you, Martha or Arthur!’

And it was Martha, who’s now 18.

It’s just been like the greatest thing in my life.

What’s been your most romantic moment?

With Kersh on our first date, we kissed on top of the giant pebble outside Bridgewater Hall in Manchester.

We go back on the anniversary, but these days I have to get a leg-up.

Because I got pregnant so quickly, we said we’ve got to carry on courting each other and we have done.

Very early on we got into the habit of really looking after each other and going on dates.

We’re romantic, we have many romantic moments.

But what was really romantic was that he wrote a one-woman play for me called The Greatest Play In The World and gave it to me as a Christmas present!

I’ve already done it in Edinburgh and I’m doing it in London in December.

What sort of mum are you?

OMG!

My mum and dad are a hard act to follow, so I’m trying to emulate them.

We have a great relationship, the four of us.

We fall out constantly, though.

There’s always a big old fight going on, with doors slamming and everything.

I’m always embarrassed if there are friends round.

It’s not the image I want to project.

But my friends one after another have always said to me, ‘This house is so

full of love.’

It means the world to me, does that.

We live in a little terraced street, and have more or less kept the same neighbours.

Are the girls going to follow in your footsteps?

Martha showed some interest in drama for a while, and now she’s fallen out of love with it.

She’s doing her A-levels and applying for uni and wants to do English.

Lyss has got the gift of contentment.

Whatever she does she’ll be great.

She’s a people person, people are fascinated by her.

She works in a charity shop on Saturday mornings.

(Image: BBC/Red Productions/Ben Blackall)

Most outrageous place you’ve been recognised?

Oh, all over the place.

I was once at a funeral and someone asked me for an autograph and I thought that was a bit off.

But honestly, I really don’t mind people coming up to me.

I soon got used to people pointing at me going, ‘Coronation Street’.

With Hayley’s pancreatic cancer storyline, I felt a big responsibility, and of course people are going to want to talk to you about their experience with cancer, and you have to engage with them.

Who were your best pals on the show?

Obviously lovely David Neilson who played my Roy, we had a great relationship.

I still see Katherine Kelly (Becky).

I can always rely on Jennie McAlpine (Fiz), Alison King (Carla) and Sally Dynevor (Sally) to lend a hand with any charity project I work on, they’re all great mates.

And in the past Suranne Jones – I loved her, I wept when she left.

(Image: Kudos/Imaginary Friends/Sister Pictures/ITV)

Were you a bit starstruck on the Broadchurch set?

The first day I was a little bit overwhelmed by it.

We did a photo shoot and it was like being in Madame Tussauds!

I was like, ‘What the hell am I doing here?’

Any more starry moments?

I had breakfast with Lenny Henry this morning.

It’s like I’m living in a parallel universe where my daughter is off to secondary school and I’m FaceTiming her and then I’m like, ‘So how are things, Lenny?’ It was just kind of weird, but I think that would be weird for anybody.

What your worst habit?

I leave a trail of mashed-up tissues wherever I go.

I always have a bit of toilet roll scrunched up my sleeve or in my pocket and it falls out and Kersh hates it.

Do you get stage fright?

I get nervous, that’s fine.

It is ridiculous, that mad adrenalin rush you get before you go on stage.

You are only actually supposed to feel like that rarely in your life, like if you are in danger or something.

Doing it every night can’t be good for you!

Though I like a dressing room – I miss my dressing room at Corrie.

I like my photos of the family around and any stuff that helps me with the part.

(Image: BBC)

How do you feel about getting older?

I feel really good about it.

I like it all.

When you’ve been a very beautiful young woman, ageing is a big thing and hard.

That moment of becoming invisible to men is really painful, but I’ve always been invisible, I really have, so there’s no loss there!

I’ve never turned heads in my life except as Hayley!

Never in my life has anyone whispered about me and I’ve thought it’s because I’m looking really hot today.

I’m settling into myself.

I’m fitter than I ever was because I walk a lot.

I’ve always thought I’ll make an ace old woman.

My mum says, ‘Old age, you can shove it!’

And she’s right.

Do you feel any different from when you were 16?

I am the same person now, in essence.

A few more wrinkles and a bigger belly!

Julie's new project....

(Image: Zoe Martin 2018)

Julie stars in the brand new play There Are No Beginnings at the Leeds Playhouse.

Set in 1975, June (Julie) is working to keep girls off the street at a time when the women of Leeds lived in fear of the Yorkshire Ripper and the authorities urged people to stay at home.

This gave birth to the Reclaim The Night movement and echoes down

the generations to this day.

‘The play specifically and emphatically is not about the Yorkshire Ripper,’ says Julie.

‘It’s about the women of Leeds – not the victims and survivors, but the ordinary girls and the effect it had on their lives.

At one point women were put under curfew and not supposed to go out after a certain time.

I’m at the line-learning stage at the moment and I do that when I take Bridie for a walk.

I’m a familiar sight, the mad woman who walks and talks to herself!’

There Are No Beginnings opens October 11 at Leeds Playhouse
description: Actress Julie Hesmondhalgh, 49, talks about her whirlwind romance, feeling like she lives in a parallel universe, and how people still love talking about Hayley from Coronation Street
